Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Plate Tectonic and Geochemical Evolution of the Young Walvis Ridge and Implications for African Plate Motion Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration: The cause of the bifurcating tracks of seamounts and seafloor swells in the Walvis Ridge area in the South Atlantic just off South Africa has been a longstanding enigma in Marine Geology and in our understanding of hotspots and the plate tectonic evolution of Africa. This project will go to sea to dredge and analyze rocks from the part of the seafloor to the west of the Walvis Ridge and examine changes from hotspot to diffuse volcanism. The present location of the Walvis hotspot and the reason for its waning volcanic activity over the last 60 Myr will also be determined. Argon trapped in minerals in the collected seafloor volcanic rocks will be used to determine the age progression of the volcano tracks. Rock, major and trace element geochemistry and isotopes will be used to see if the younger rocks in the bifurcated tracks can be linked to the older Walvis Ridge. Multibeam bathymetric mapping and a map of seafloor magnetics will also be generated to examine structural trends and plate tectonic motions of this part of the ocean floor. Broader impacts of the work include international collaboration with a complementary German effort that is studying the older part of the Walvis Ridge, K-12 teacher and graduate and undergraduate student training, and support of a PI whose gender is under-represented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hotspot trails on the African Plate are essential to global plate tectonic models as the circum-Atlantic and Tethyian plate systems are dominantly continental. Given its longevity, the Walvis Ridge in the South Atlantic represents the most important hotspot trail on the African Plate with ~130 million years of continuous volcanism. It is a rare example of a seamount trail that can be connected with a massive large-igneous province (LIP) that is located today on both the South American and African continents, making up the so-called Paranà-Etendeka continental flood basalt. With this it represents one of the few “primary hotspots” consistent with the thermal plume model. However, around 60 million years ago, the morphological expression of the Walvis Ridge changed drastically from a robust 200 km wide aseismic ridge into a 400 km wide region of diffuse and diminished volcanism. As a result, the “young” end of the Walvis Ridge, also called the Guyot Province, may include two or more subtracks, one ending at Tristan da Cunha Island and another at Gough Island, more than 400 km to the SSE, which is at odds with the classical definition of a narrow, linear and continuous primary hotspot trail.

Before our project, the Walvis Ridge age-progression was based on only few data of mostly poor quality. This resulted in a number of critical questions. What causes the transition to the diffuse volcanism? Where is the current hotspot located? Why has volcanic activity been severely diminished over the last 60 million years? Does the Walvis Ridge represent a unique example of a “dying” hotspot or a large plume splitting up into smaller plumelets, or even a missing plume, with volcanism explained by lithospheric extension and melts originating in the shallow upper mantle? The answers have enormous implications for African plate motion and global tectonic modeling. If no systematic age progression exists along the Walvis Ridge in the Guyot Province, it means that we can't use it in absolute plate motion models for the African plate. It would force us to rethink global plate tectonic modeling, most of which are based on the unverified assumption that the Walvis Ridge represents a fixed primary hotspot above a deeply-rooted mantle plume. However, if we can verify that this hotspot track has a clear age progression and if we can geochemically link the young subtracks with the older, more robust Walvis Ridge, then we can say that this particular ridge is a true “primary” hotspot track, which in turn will provide powerful constraints on plate tectonic modeling and hotspot evolution.

We successfully carried out seagoing expedition MV1203 on the R/V Melville for in total 49 days (from 11 February to 30 March, 2012) with port calls in Cape Town and Cape Town (South Africa). In this cruise we mapped in total 50 seamounts in the Guyot Province and placed in total 62 dredges of which 47 contained relatively fresh basaltic rocks that are extremely valuable for age dating and performing geochemical analyses. In total we carried out 120 incremental heating experiments with the 40Ar/39Ar geochronology technique in the OSU Argon Geochronology Laboratory, resulting in a single PhD thesis (Schnur 2017). This large new age data set provides important insights into the volcanic and geodynamic history of the Walvis Ridge.

First, Tristan da Cunha, traditionally considered one of the two proposed hotspot locations, does not align with the overall age progression formed by other Walvis Ridge seamounts. These islands are 6-14 million years younger than neighboring seamounts, with all dated island volcanics being younger than 1.4 million years. This confirms that Tristan is an outlier with respect to nearby seamounts, that asthenospheric flow is channeling plume material northwestward towards Tristan, and that an eruptive center about 400 km to the south is tracing the actual path of the plate over the plume.

Second, we demonstrate that volcanism in the Guyot Province is controlled by lithospheric thickness, the presence of fracture zones, and the proximity of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. The upper sub-track of seamounts, formed on younger lithosphere, shows distinct on-ridge volcanism at its old end, and is overall more continuous and higher volume than the lower track. The lower sub-track, emplaced on older lithosphere, is more discontinuous, lower-volume, and more often expressed as seamount lineaments aligned with fracture zones. Both tracks seem to exhibit fracture-zone-modulated volcanism at ages younger then about 26 million years (upper) and 35 million years (lower) that suggests that the Walvis plume is currently experiencing a weakening in its volcanic output, with volcanism seemingly only possible when preexisting weak zones (e.g. fracture zones) are present in the overriding African plate.

Finally, previously-published absolute plate motion models for the African Plate do not accurately predict our new age data, suggesting these new ages conversely could significantly impact global plate circuits.
